posts.text:
I think the reason why these questions might seem simultaneously frivolous and challenging is that "intelligence" is a poorly characterized term that conflates several concepts.

We'd be better served framing the discourse in terms of information storage/movement and computational power/complexity.

reply_context.text:
On "Intelligence"...
* Is Wikipedia intelligent? (the database, not the community)
* Is a decision tree intelligent? (qua frozen but arbitrarily complex decision process) 
* Is Microsoft intelligent?
* Is a dolphin intelligent?
* Is a school of fish intelligent?
* Is a ribosome intelligent?

posts.text: I'm increasingly of the opinion that "intelligence" is just having the right (meta)heuristics, so the fact that machines can learn and compose heuristics to exhibit "intelligent behavior" shouldn't be surprising. The "problem" is our non-acceptance that "intelligence" is just a sleight of hand.

i.e. not "as a decision maker".

posts.text: There is a very real possibility that chatting with LLMs will replace search as the dominant UX paradigm for information retrieval. If that happens, it is critical that people continue to be able to find information about current events, i.e. these partnerships will be important.

reply_context.text:
I think this article is conflating two issues which it is important to acknowledge are orthogonal:
* forcing journalists to use AI - LLMs replacing labor/quality
* whether or not journalistic publishers should partner with LLM inference providers - LLMs replacing *search*
